profileText: (Great-grandson of Charles Hooks), a Senator from Georgia; born in Cedartown, Polk County, Ga., February 3, 1868; attended the common schools and graduated from the University of Georgia at Athens in 1890; engaged in the general insurance business and banking at Cedartown; served as private secretary to United States Senator Alexander S. Clay 1904-1909; member, State senate 1911-1912; Director of the United States Census Bureau 1913-1915, when he resigned to become a member of the Federal Trade Commission; Acting Secretary of the Department of Commerce 1913-1915; member of the Federal Trade Commission 1915-1918, when he resigned to become a candidate for United States Senator; chairman of the commission 1917-1918; elected as a Democrat to the United States Senate in 1918; reelected in 1924 and in 1930 and served from March 4, 1919, until his death; member of the National Forest Reservation Commission 1929-1932; died in Washington, D.C., April 18, 1932; funeral services were held in the Chamber of the United States Senate; interment in Greenwood Cemetery, Cedartown, Ga.

researchRecord.name: 15 items in the Charles Holmes Herty papers concerning protective legislation for American kaolin. Also 9 letters (1919-1930) in 4 other collections.

1905-1913. 4 feet. Personal and professional correspondence, speeches, receipts, and documents relating to his insurance and real estate transactions and work as personal secretary to U.S. Senator Alexander Stephens Clay. While this collection does not cover his years in the U.S. Senate, the political series contains correspondence with Senator Augustus Bacon and other Georgia politicians during Harris' tenure as state Democratic chairman; correspondence with Alexander Stephens Clay while Harris served as his personal secretary; and correspondence regarding Hoke Smith's campaign for the U.S. Senate in 1910. Finding aid.
